i've finally figured out what it is about jack nicholson that freaks me out so badly-- one of the main things aside from the crazy-eyed intensity, that is. it's his diction-- he has such precise diction and he speaks so clearly and correctly, it can come across as really, really eerie. and then when he uses certain casual words ("don'tcha" comes to mind cus he just said it on the tv) it's so super creepy, it's like he's *trying* to be casual in a way that's unnatural to him. 

this came up b/c i'm watching kubrick's version of 'the shining' for the first time; i've always avoided it because of how creepy i find nicholson, but i guess now i was ready for it cus i'm really enjoying it. it's shot really brilliantly and while nicholson's really not who i think stephen king was picturing when he wrote jack torrence, i think he's playing the character well. i do still prefer the miniseries, because it's more faithful to the book, but this is enjoyable. :) though oh my god, all that nails-on-the-chalkboard screeching music is giving me a headache, lol.

i had pondered writing a post about coming out day, but then i read a bunch of posts that said everything better than i could have. for your consideration : + "fear, loathing and 'coming out'" by + discusses the sexuality quiz show. + a lot of you have probably seen the heterosexuality questionnaire, but it's worth reading again, i think. + pondering the 'unified theory of gay' by thingswithwings at dreamwidth. another friend had a really interesting post, but it's flocked, sadly. but she made what is, i think, the best point so far which is that we often don't think of ourselves as being on the front lines of any kind of equality struggle, but we are. we have to do the hard work of coming out now because unless we do, there likely won't ever *be* a world in which no one assumes anything about anyone's sexuality, a world in which there's no need to qualify "i like girls" any more than there is need to qualify "i like brunettes" now. my friend also linked this youtube vid in which a guy who makes greeting cards shows off some coming out cards, and at the end thanks the gay friends he had in school for showing him that gay people were real people too. that's why we have to do it (to paraphrase my friend) to build a world where people know we exist. i've also been having really, really, really messed up dreams lately. not nightmares, just like, dreams containing people i haven't seen or thought of in years, really random and sometimes disturbing (in a where-the-fuck-did-that-come-from way) situations, and just a lot of stuff that leaves me waking up going "what the everloving fuck, yo?" i woke up this morning from one such and it kind of put a weird spin on the whole morning. sigh. but i just cleaned and organized my room and vacuumed, which always makes me happy. i'd love to know what the gene is that codes people to take comfort from cleaning, b/c it definitely runs in my family, and it's very strange. rearranging furniture, too, i get such a kick out of that. it's time for lunch. ♥

<lj-cut text="musings on flash forward, cut for spoilers">i'm sitting here with the second episode of flash forward and wondering if this is going to turn out to be a huge let down or if i'm going to end up loving it. on the one hand i can see the punchline of the show being about how you can't avoid destiny; but on the other hand i don't really know if i want to sign myself up for a season (or two or whatever) of getting invested in these characters and the story when most of what i've seen so far is gearing me toward not wanting the flash forwards to come true. i mean it'll be cool to see how the flash forwards come true, but otoh i'd like to see what happens if/when someone succeeds in avoiding theirs. idk. i'm not totally hooked on it right now, but i'm interested. the creepy/psychic kids thing is the part i'm most interested in at the moment, and finding out if there were any other people awake during the blackouts. soooo yes. anyone else w/thoughts on the show, i'd love to hear 'em. :D

"he who foresees calamity experiences it twice over", that's what he said, yes? huh. definitely another mark in the "you can't escape destiny" column. :x</lj-cut>

the next show i introduce myself to is probably going to be big bang theory. i have the first bunch of episodes DL'd and have been told repeatedly that i need to watch it, so, yeah watch out for that. :"D

so let me preface this by saying, i'm too young to have watched the original series of star trek when it was first airing. in fact, i'm young enough that i grew up in the heyday of the next generation-- for years it was the only TV we were ever allowed to watch during dinner, and one of the only shows i ever watched as a kid that aired later than 6pm. i've seen most TNG episodes several times, and while i haven't watched in a few years, i can still talk about the characters and some plot points with decent familiarity. i have seen a lot of TOS, but not enough to really be solid on the continuity of the story, or any of the characters. i know DS9 and voyager much better; far less well than TNG, but i was still (to my recollection, anyway) in middle school when they aired, so i remember watching new episodes as they came out. the whole point of this is that while i absolutely 100% consider myself a trekkie, i am not at all able to say i *know* TOS well. i loved it, sure, and still do, whenever i happen to catch a rerun. but i'm not someone who is/was likely to be sitting in the theater this past weekend trembling with trepidation in case the movie didn't get canon /just right/. i wouldn't have known if they had or hadn't. but what i do know is how trek-- all the shows, all the episodes-- makes me feel. why i like them-- no, love them so much, even with the camp and stereotypes and often issues with race and gender that make me cringe. because-- and this probably isn't a shock to anyone who knows me-- i'm weak like a weak, weak thing for strong characterization-- for characters who are real people, flawed and sometimes prejudiced and sometimes ignorant but real for all that. and so for me, trek has always been about the people i've come to love through the years. i feel about it the way i feel about LotR in some respects-- in a way that knows i could never possibly fathom the ways it's shaped my taste in books, movies, tv shows -- though i can tell you right now, i'd never have lost my shit over kara thrace if i hadn't also loved tasha yar to the depths of my ten-year-old soul. okay, okay, coming to the point of this post. The Movie. i saw it on sunday and was completely fucking floored. there wasn't a moment of it that i didn't passionately adore. i'm not saying it was perfect-- far from it! but that's what made it star trek. for all the plot holes and miniskirts and cosmic coincidences, it was so utterly harmonious with every experience of the show i've ever had, that i couldn't not love it. it did exactly what JJ wanted it to do-- remind everyone that TOS is where it all began, and that it spawned such a huge franchise for a good fucking reason. IMO the movie didn't reboot TOS canon-- it gave it a paint job and put some high-grade oil in the engine, and set it loose on a flat stretch of highway. what's under the hood hasn't changed-- round, flawed, deep characters who are strong in personality and fierce in feeling, whose relationships with each other define them and make them better people. i read somewhere the actors are in contract for a sequel. i cannot wait. there are few movies i can think of that i'll be more excited about in the coming years-- 'cause this is more than just fulfilling the pitter-patter of my geeky little heart. this is taking something that in a lot of ways helped define my childhood, and giving me a whole new score of reasons to love it as an adult. and i can't think of anything that makes me happier. ps, i'm seeing it again tomorrow. XD

a long time ago i made an LJ purely for keeping track of my fiction. i have this habit when i'm bored of picking up the nearest available piece of paper and writing on it-- when i worked at faces or blockbuster or barnes & noble, those were pieces of receipt tape. in office jobs it'd be a piece of looseleaf or the back of a sheet from the recycling bin. and i can't tell you how many times i would come home and realize it wasn't in my pocket anymore, or worse, a few days later realize i'd put it through the wash. fucking infuriating.

anyway, the point is i've been writing parts of my book on that journal for a while now, and i'm surprised at how well it's working for me. it's a lot less daunting than a word document; when i'm ready to write, i just make a new post, and i don't have to worry about where it fits in with the rest of the story just yet, or the transitions, or any of that other stuff. i just write what is in my head to write, and edit it in comments later so i can see the evolution of what i wrote. it's really baffling me how easy it's making it for me to just get shit out on the "page"... like, i'd say my worst flaw in the technical aspects of writing is how much i hate to write badly.... which i know you have to, that's what editing is about, but if i get stuck on something it's really hard for me to put down a crappy description or some shitty dialogue just to get me through to the next part. but with this it's not as hard, both b/c i know i can just hit post and go to something else, and b/c i know i can edit it later-- and editing a three-page entry is a lot less daunting than editing a section of a 50 page manuscript.

idk, i guess this is just to say that i'm writing, like actually regularly writing something that comes from my own head, and that i like what it is that's coming out. it's been a long time since i could say that... any of it. 

today is also six months since i moved out of the house on russell street. coincidence... fuck no.

♥ emily

my whole life i've never been a cd-buying person; it's always been too hard to conscience spending $15 on a cd i don't know if i'll even like, so i get most of my music taste from the radio or from other people. but there are albums i've either been given as a gift or bought on a whim or known from the second i heard one of the songs that i had to own, that have ended up rocking my world. here are the top 26 (cus of course i couldn't pare down, lol). and holy fuck, did this take me a long time! in no particular order.... 1) indigo girls, self titled : i got this album as a gift from my favorite aunt for my tenth birthday; it was the first CD i ever owned. i remember it vividly; i loved it from the very first second i put it in. i joke that i was predisposed to being gay b/c of listening to this as i was growing up, but in reality i can't think of an important time in my life that i don't associate with one or more of the songs on this disc. 2) dave matthews band, under the table and dreaming : this was one of the cds i got during my columbia house music club phase in 8th grade, and i have never regretted it. i am deeply in love with dave's voice, and the band's ability to rock out beautifully and intricately using a wide variety of instruments and sounds. coming from a combination classical music and classic rock background, i love everything about dmb-- they really make music as art, and this was the album that first introduced me to their awesomeness. 3) korn, follow the leader : laugh all you want, but i was fifteen when i first listened to this album, and i really got that music didn't have to be about anything more than reaching in and ripping your guts out. totally contradicts what i said above about DMB, but sometimes you just need to scream, or listen to other people scream, and korn is so, so good for that. i don't listen to the album anymore really, but there are a few tracks from it, and from other korn albums, that i still dig when i'm in an angry mood. 4) bush, 6teen stone : another vestige of columbia house- i think i'd heard one song by bush and decided to order this on a whim, and was greatly rewarded. gavin rossdale has a *gorgeous* voice, as well as knowing how to seriously rock out, and i love his weird angsty lyrics. 'glycerine' has a special place in my heart, and still sometimes makes me a little misty-eyed. 5) green day, dookie : the second cd i ever owned, which i hated at first because i was completely ignorant of anything approaching modern music-- i was 10 and was pretty much only allowed to listen to NPR and classic rock, lol. i dragged it out again when i was 12 or so and listened again, and loved it. this was the album that got me into liking modern alternative rock. 6) joni mitchell, blue : one of my earliest memories is of driving somewhere with my mom, sitting in the back seat of the car, while she sang along to 'carey' on the tapedeck. joni's been a part of my life forever, my music taste wouldn't be what it is without her. she's why i like tori and imogen heap and regina spektor; she gave me that appreciation for a voice so soaring and breathtaking it only needs one instrument to complement it, and sometimes not even that. 7) tracy chapman, new beginning : wooo, empowering lyrics meet fucking ridiculously stunning voice! i got given this album for christmas 2001, and i still know it forwards and backwards. listening to it got me listening to her earlier stuff, too, which is also ridiculously amazing, and started a movement for me to start listening to older music (ie: not stuff that had come out while i was in high school, lol). i really do love when artists sing good music about activism, and she really gets me fired up. :) 8) tori amos, little earthquakes : first heard this album when i was 13 staying at my aunt's for a week during the summer. i liked it then, but when i picked it up again three years later it hit me in a vastly different way, and i was totally hooked. 'happy phantom' especially struck me; later on i used it to try out for the m&c's. :} 9) ani difranco, little plastic castle : i'm not an ani freak. i like a lot of her stuff, but this is the only album of hers that i LOVE. bought it senior year of high school when i was mad about a lot of things and didn't know how to express it; kept on listening especially thru my parents' divorce two years later. her voice just grabs me-- to be cliche, she puts the grrr in girl, lol, but without being fucking crazy like courtney love. 'deep dish' is one of my favorite songs, and 'gravel' is *always* fun when i'm pissed off. 10) maroon 5, songs about jane : if i were to order this list by biggest impact on my life, this album would be in the top five. this was the soundtrack to my junior year at mount holyoke, a year that was full of drama but that ultimately ended up solidifying my friendships with the group of girls i call my tet. there is not a song on this album that doesn't call up a vivid memory of that year. 11) panic at the disco, a fever you can't sweat out : this album isn't so much life changing as that it's the soundtrack to a really important time in my life. (the phrases "kitchen of 154" and "spaceship genre" are critical as well ;)) 12) guster, lost and gone forever : i made a point of not listening to this album (or any of guster) when i was in early high school because they were like THE trendy band at the time. but when a friend played this for me i was really hooked. i wouldn't say it changed my life so much as it changed my music taste; this was when i started to care less about identifying with the hard rock / metal scene and just started listening to everything i could lay hands on. 13) eve 6, self titled : this sits right beside maroon 5 as being the soundtrack to that spring and summer of 2004. i'd known some of it before, but this was the first time i had the whole thing, and i was in love. every song on it means something special to me and/or conjures up clear memories of that time, especially 'jesus nite lite' and 'open road song'. i can still put this on any old time and be thrilled to hear it. 14) the cure, greatest hits : god, i'd always loved the cure, but i didn't know it, lol. this i found used at turn it up for like $3 and it electrified me. i never realized how deeply i loved the sound, the vocals, the lyrics, just everything about it, this sort of 80s punk puts me in the best kind of mood, and this was the album that made me realize it. since then i've made a point of getting to know 15) red hot chili peppers, by the way : is not my favorite album of RHCP's, but was the first one i ever paid attention to as a whole. i remember it came out the summer i was working with my dad, and there were a few singles that'd be frequently on the radio... i liked the songs so much i started paying more attention to RHCP as a band, and now they're one of my absolute all-time favorites. 16) smashing pumpkins, mellon collie and the infinite sadness : ahaha sometimes i think the smashing pumpkins (this album specifically) were responsible for the path my music taste took in high school. i bought this the summer after 8th grade and within a month it was the most-listened to cd in my arsenal; made me realize that what i wanted in music by and large was guts and glory, complexity and emotion. it led me to a lot of other bands i probly would never have otherwise known. (i also used to tell people that billy corgan was my cousin and he'd changed the L to an R in his last name cus it sounded cooler.
